; Let's do some math!
; Calculate: (15 + 27) * 2 = 84

MOV R0, #15    ; First number
MOV R1, #27    ; Second number

; Your calculation here

HALT
hints: First add R0 and R1, store in R2
Then multiply R2 by 2
Use ADD R2, R0 then ADD R2, R1, then MUL R2, #2

beginner.title: ü§î The Decision Maker

advanced.title: üóº Recursive Tower of Power
advanced.prompt: Build the Tower of Recursion! Calculate 2^5 (32) using recursive multiplication instead of loops. Each call multiplies by 2.
advanced.realWorldContext: Like calculating compound interest, exponential growth models, or fractal generation - recursion models self-similar patterns!
advanced.starter:
; The Recursive Tower Challenge!
; Calculate 2^5 = 32 using recursion
; power(base, exp) = base * power(base, exp-1)

MOV R0, #2    ; Base
MOV R1, #5    ; Exponent
CALL power
HALT

power:
; Your recursive power function here
; Base case: if exp = 0, return 1
; Recursive: return base * power(base, exp-1)
RET
hints: Base case: if R1 = 0, return 1
Recursive case: multiply R0 by power(R0, R1-1)
Use stack to preserve registers across calls

advanced.title: üîÆ Hash Table Wizard
advanced.prompt: Master the ancient art of hashing! Create a hash table and insert the magic numbers 17, 27, 37 using linear probing to resolve collisions.
advanced.realWorldContext: Like dictionaries in Python, objects in JavaScript, or database indexing - hash tables power fast lookups everywhere!
advanced.starter:
; The Ancient Hash Table Grimoire!

; Insert: 17, 27, 37 (all hash to 7, causing collisions!)

MOV R2, #10

STORE [R1], R0
ADD R1, #2

advanced.title: üßÆ Expression Calculator Sage
advanced.prompt: Become a calculation sage! Evaluate the postfix expression '5 3 + 2 4 * -' (which equals -3) using stack-based computation.
advanced.realWorldContext: Like calculators, compilers, and expression parsers - postfix evaluation is how computers process mathematical expressions!
advanced.starter:
; The Sage's Calculation Challenge!

; Actually: 5 3 + 2 4 * - means: push 5, push 3, add (=8), push 2, push 4, multiply (=8), subtract (8-8=0)
; Let's use: 7 2 + 3 * = (7+2)*3 = 27

; Stack operations for: 7 2 + 3 *
MOV R0, #15000  ; Stack base
MOV R1, #15000  ; Stack pointer

; Your sage wisdom here
; Process: 7, 2, +, 3, *

HALT
hints: For numbers: push onto stack, increment stack pointer
For operators: pop two values, compute, push result
Final result is the only value left on stack

expert.title: ‚öôÔ∏è Compiler Optimization Guru
expert.prompt: Become a compiler optimization master! Optimize the expression 'x*12 + x*4' to 'x*16' using bit shifts. Given x=5, compute efficiently.
expert.realWorldContext: Like the optimizations in GCC, LLVM, or V8 JavaScript engine - making code run faster through clever transformations!
expert.starter:
; The Optimization Master Challenge!
; Optimize: x*12 + x*4 = x*16 = x << 4
; Given x = 5, result should be 80
; But let's be clever: x*12 = x*8 + x*4 = (x<<3) + (x<<2)
; So: x*12 + x*4 = (x<<3) + (x<<2) + (x<<2) = (x<<3) + 2*(x<<2)
; Or simply: x*16 = x << 4

MOV R0, #5    ; x = 5

; Your optimization mastery here
; Calculate x*16 = 80 using only shifts and adds

HALT
hints: x*16 = x << 4 (left shift by 4 positions)
This is much faster than multiplication
Use SHL R1, #4 after copying x to R1

expert.title: üèóÔ∏è Memory Allocator Architect
expert.prompt: Design a memory management system! Implement a heap allocator that can allocate 32 bytes from a 128-byte heap with proper block headers.
expert.realWorldContext: Like malloc() in C, new in C++, or garbage collectors in Java/Python - memory management is the foundation of all software!
expert.starter:
; The Memory Architecture Challenge!
; Heap: 128 bytes starting at 17000
; Block format: [size:2][free_flag:2][data...]

MOV R0, #1    ; Free flag
STORE [17002], R0

; Your memory architecture here
; Allocate 32 bytes and return pointer to data area

CALL allocate

HALT

allocate:
; Your allocation algorithm here
; Input: R1 = requested size
; Output: R0 = pointer to allocated data (or 0 if failed)
RET

asserts.description: R0 should point to data area (17004)
Block should be marked as allocated (0)

hints: Find first free block with size >= requested
Split block if much larger than needed
Return pointer to data area (header + 4)

expert.title: ‚ôªÔ∏è Garbage Collector Sage
expert.prompt: Master the art of automatic memory management! Implement mark-and-sweep garbage collection for objects with reference chains.
expert.realWorldContext: Like the garbage collectors in Java, C#, Python, and JavaScript - automatic memory management that powers modern languages!
expert.starter:
; The Garbage Collection Mastery!
; Object format: [mark_bit:2][size:2][data...]

; Object A at 18000: size=6, contains reference to B
MOV R0, #0    ; mark bit
STORE [18000], R0
MOV R0, #6    ; size
STORE [18002], R0
MOV R0, #18008 ; reference to object B
STORE [18004], R0

; Object B at 18008: size=4, leaf object
MOV R0, #0    ; mark bit
STORE [18008], R0
MOV R0, #4    ; size
STORE [18010], R0
MOV R0, #100  ; data
STORE [18012], R0

; Object C at 18016: size=4, unreferenced
MOV R0, #0    ; mark bit
STORE [18016], R0
MOV R0, #4    ; size
STORE [18018], R0
MOV R0, #200  ; data
STORE [18020], R0

; Root points to object A
MOV R0, #18000
STORE [19000], R0

; Your garbage collection mastery here
CALL mark_phase
CALL sweep_phase
HALT

mark_phase:
; Mark all reachable objects starting from roots
RET

sweep_phase:
; Free all unmarked objects
RET

asserts.description: Object A should be marked (reachable from root)
Object B should be marked (referenced by A)

hints: Mark phase: recursively mark objects reachable from roots
Follow references in object data to find connected objects
Sweep phase: scan heap and free unmarked objects

expert.starter:
; üéÅ THE LEGENDARY MYSTERY BOX üéÅ
; 
; MISSION: The Mystery Box Algorithm
; 
; You are given a magical sequence that follows these rules:
; 1. Start with the Fibonacci sequence: 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8...
; 2. For each Fibonacci number F(n):
;    - If F(n) is even: store F(n) * 2 at memory[22000 + n*2]
;    - If F(n) is odd: store F(n) + 10 at memory[22000 + n*2]
; 3. Calculate the sum of the first 6 transformed values
; 4. Apply Caesar cipher (shift +3) to the result if > 100
; 5. Store final result in R0
;
; Expected sequence: F(1)=1‚Üí11, F(2)=1‚Üí11, F(3)=2‚Üí4, F(4)=3‚Üí13, F(5)=5‚Üí15, F(6)=8‚Üí16
; Sum: 11+11+4+13+15+16 = 70
; Since 70 < 100, no cipher needed
; Final result: 70

; Your legendary algorithm here
; Combine: Fibonacci + Conditionals + Arrays + Arithmetic + Cryptography

MOV R0, #0    ; Final result
MOV R1, #1    ; F(n-1)
MOV R2, #1    ; F(n)
MOV R3, #22000 ; Memory base
MOV R4, #6    ; Count
MOV R5, #0    ; Sum accumulator

; üéØ Your mastery of ALL concepts here!

HALT

asserts.description: R0 should contain the mystery result (70)

expert.goldStandardSolution:
; üèÜ GOLD STANDARD SOLUTION - Revealed after completion!
; This is how a master would solve it:

MOV R0, #0
MOV R1, #1
MOV R2, #1
MOV R3, #22000
MOV R4, #6
MOV R5, #0

fib_loop:
MOV R6, R2
AND R6, #1
JNZ odd_case
MOV R6, R2
MUL R6, #2
JMP store_value
odd_case:
MOV R6, R2
ADD R6, #10
store_value:
STORE [R3], R6
ADD R5, R6
ADD R3, #2
MOV R7, R2
ADD R2, R1
MOV R1, R7
DEC R4
JNZ fib_loop
CMP R5, #100
JLE no_cipher
ADD R5, #3
no_cipher:
MOV R0, R5
HALT
